headline.main: Arrival of the "Adriatic" at Savannah.; CAPT. DURHAM'S NARRATIVE OF HIS ADVENTURES.

docs.lead_paragraph: The American bark Adriatic, which became famous from her disastrous collision with the French steamer Lyonnais, in November, 1856, and still an object of interest from her recent seizures by French authorities at Marseilles, her confiscation the Court of Admiralty, and her subsequent escape arrived safely at this port at an early hour yesterday.

docs.snippet: ANNOYANCES IN RAILROAD CARS--A correspondent complains, in a communication which we publish to-day, of sufferings endured from open windows in cars. Many passengers, and especially ladies, he avers, are in the habit of greatly discommoding those...
docs.lead_paragraph: ANNOYANCES IN RAILROAD CARS--A correspondent complains, in a communication which we publish to-day, of sufferings endured from open windows in cars. Many passengers, and especially ladies, he avers, are in the habit of greatly discommoding those around them by pertinaciously keeping open the windows next which they sit,

docs.snippet: In the Senate of the United States, yesterday morning, Mr. STUART, of Michigan, had the floor, and spoke at length on the Kansas question, taking the ground that the Lecompton Constitution was fraudulent. He expresses astonishment that the President...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the Senate of the United States, yesterday morning, Mr. STUART, of Michigan, had the floor, and spoke at length on the Kansas question, taking the ground that the Lecompton Constitution was fraudulent. He expresses astonishment that the President should desire to bring Kansas into the Union, after saying in his message that she was in a state of rebellion.

headline.main: AFFAIRS IN HAVANA.; The Financial Difficulties of Cuba Before the Spanish Cortes--Gen. Concha's Excersion--The Sugar Crop--Miscellaneous.

headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; INTERESTING DEBATE IN BOTH HOUSES. Dispatches from the Utah Expedistio--The Witness Wolcot to be Delivered up to the Authorities, &c. Tremendous Crowd in the Senate Chamber. By Telegraph to the New-York Times. INTERESTING FROM WASHINGTON. Magnrtie Telegraph Ca's Off??--No. 19 Wallst, and 181 Broadway Senator Douglas' Speech on the Kansas Question.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. DOUGLAS spoke this evening three hours to an overcrowded audience. He first reviewed his own course on the Slavery question, since 1843, to show not be had acquiesced in the Missouri Compromise until the principle of popular sovereignty was introduced, when he embraced it, and afterwards applied t to Kansas. All he asked now was that it should be fairly carried out,--and this, he went on to show, the Lecompton Constitution did not do.

headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; Report of the Republican Minority of the House Sepcial Committee on Kansas--The Matteson Case, & c. General Calhoun's Action Giving Kansas to the Free-State Men. Fat Contracts in Connection with the Utah Campaign. By Telegraph to the New-York Times. Magenetic Telegraphic ?? Officers--No. 49 Wall-st., and 181 Broadway. Stampede of the Lecomptonites in the House---The Result in the Senate Doubtful. IMPORTANT FROM WASHINGTON.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Administration men are working desperately to control the stampede in the House against Le compton There are some five millions of dollars worth of contracts in connection with the Utah campaign, which are being used as levers, as far as possible, to affect votes. How and where, will be clearly apparent when the vote comes to be taken.

headline.main: LAW INTELLIGENCE.; COURT CALENDAR Motion to Discharge Mr. Mott from yesterday--Arguments of Mr. Ga Nun and Judge Foote--Decision Reserved. THE UNION BANK FRAUDS. COURT OF SPECIAL SESSIONS.
